pull_request.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw:
Yes, that's what I mean. If you have the following files:

```
src/Filename.cc
src/Filename.hh
```

Then `Filename.cc` should use `#include "Filename.hh"`. In this situation, the worst case scenario is that someone accidentally writes `#include <Filename.hh>`. If this causes issues (e.g. the compiler selects a file called `Filename.hh` that was installed by some other library, because we don't install `Filename.hh` ourselves), in the vast majority of cases it should cause some very obvious build issues that we will catch during our own build time. That is a much more manageable (and less likely) problem than shipping off headers that might break things when users try to build with them.
content.html:
Yes, that's what I mean. If you have the following files:

src/Filename.cc
src/Filename.hh

Then Filename.cc should use #include "Filename.hh". In this situation, the worst case scenario is that someone accidentally writes #include <Filename.hh>. If this causes issues (e.g. the compiler selects a file called Filename.hh that was installed by some other library, because we don't install Filename.hh ourselves), in the vast majority of cases it should cause some very obvious build issues that we will catch during our own build time. That is a much more manageable (and less likely) problem than shipping off headers that might break things when users try to build with them.

pull_request.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw:
Hypothetically, it could have a slight benefit to compile time, but I doubt it would be perceptible to a human.

There's a big drawback, though: There could be other files from other libraries with the name `Filename.hh`. In principle, using `#include "Filename.hh"` should ensure that the compiler chooses to use our local version of `Filename.hh`, but all it takes is one little slip-up for someone to accidentally write `#include <Filename.hh>`, and then we're at risk of the compiler choosing the wrong version of the file. So I would strongly protest using that scheme for installed headers. We should, however, do exactly that for source files inside the `src/` directory when they are including non-installed headers that live inside of the `src/` directory.

If we want to use quotes for stylistic reasons, we can do that. It wouldn't be doing any favors for the compiler, but it also wouldn't do any noticeable harm, as long as we keep the `ignition/common/`.
content.html:
Hypothetically, it could have a slight benefit to compile time, but I doubt it would be perceptible to a human.

There's a big drawback, though: There could be other files from other libraries with the name Filename.hh. In principle, using #include "Filename.hh" should ensure that the compiler chooses to use our local version of Filename.hh, but all it takes is one little slip-up for someone to accidentally write #include <Filename.hh>, and then we're at risk of the compiler choosing the wrong version of the file. So I would strongly protest using that scheme for installed headers. We should, however, do exactly that for source files inside the src/ directory when they are including non-installed headers that live inside of the src/ directory.

If we want to use quotes for stylistic reasons, we can do that. It wouldn't be doing any favors for the compiler, but it also wouldn't do any noticeable harm, as long as we keep the ignition/common/.

content.raw: humm interesting. Do you think it would be possibly more efficient to include `"Filename.hh"` in headers and `<ignition/common/Filename.hh>` in source files?
content.html: humm interesting. Do you think it would be possibly more efficient to include "Filename.hh" in headers and <ignition/common/Filename.hh> in source files?

pull_request.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw: It was intentional. While the ISO standard is somewhat nebulous about the distinction between `"..."` and `<...>`, in most compiler implementations the meaning of `"..."` is to search for the header in the same directory as the current file before resorting to the lookup procedure used by `<...>`. However, we're specifying `ignition/common/*.hh`, which (if I understand correctly) means that the compiler will always fail to find the file in the "same directory" as the current file, because it will be looking for a subdirectory called `ignition/common/` within the subdirectory `ignition/common/`. Therefore, I think we're misleading the compiler by using quotes. (...not that it really makes a noticeable practical difference, since it will always fall back on the behavior of `<...>` anyway.)
content.html: It was intentional. While the ISO standard is somewhat nebulous about the distinction between "..." and <...>, in most compiler implementations the meaning of "..." is to search for the header in the same directory as the current file before resorting to the lookup procedure used by <...>. However, we're specifying ignition/common/*.hh, which (if I understand correctly) means that the compiler will always fail to find the file in the "same directory" as the current file, because it will be looking for a subdirectory called ignition/common/ within the subdirectory ignition/common/. Therefore, I think we're misleading the compiler by using quotes. (...not that it really makes a noticeable practical difference, since it will always fall back on the behavior of <...> anyway.)

pull_request.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw: `ignition/common/Export.hh` essentially exists for internal use (but it needs to be installed because of how headers work). If it needs to be used, then it will be included by whichever `ignition/common` header needs it. In the event that no `ignition/common` header needs it, then the user will not have any use for it either.
content.html: ignition/common/Export.hh essentially exists for internal use (but it needs to be installed because of how headers work). If it needs to be used, then it will be included by whichever ignition/common header needs it. In the event that no ignition/common header needs it, then the user will not have any use for it either.

content.raw: This branch is passing with a Stable status on Jenkins [Windows](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/355/), [Xenial](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/109/), and [Homebrew](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/131/). I believe this is ready for a final review. We're just 2 approvals away from having stable support for the core of `ign-common` across all platforms.

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw:
I've made the changes you recommended in 3d476c0

Rather than having a needlessly complicated if-statement like what I suggested, I just did what you said and then put in a comment to explain the situation. Hopefully anyone who tweaks the header implementation will read that comment first.

Interestingly, on Xenial, clang will happily accept the GCC pragmas `GCC diagnostic push` and `GCC diagnostic pop` and correctly suppress the warnings. Does it not accept those pragmas on OSX?
content.html:
I've made the changes you recommended in 3d476c0

Rather than having a needlessly complicated if-statement like what I suggested, I just did what you said and then put in a comment to explain the situation. Hopefully anyone who tweaks the header implementation will read that comment first.

Interestingly, on Xenial, clang will happily accept the GCC pragmas GCC diagnostic push and GCC diagnostic pop and correctly suppress the warnings. Does it not accept those pragmas on OSX?
